(State Western Hemisphere Regional): &lt;!--td {border: 1px solid #ccc;}br {mso-data-placement:same-cell;}--&gt;<!--td {border: 1px solid #ccc;}br {mso-data-placement:same-cell;}-->In FY 2018, LAC/Regional Program plans to fund the development of a community of practice of experts and practitioners in Washington and LAC to build an evidence base that will help USAID to better integrate gender issues in citizen security programs and facilitate best practices. This will include donor and stakeholder mapping, gap analysis, etc. and will mainstream a gender-sensitive approach for crime and violence prevention programs. The implementer would conduct a review of existing evidence, identify gaps in knowledge, and then conduct research to fill those gaps. USAID will actively share the outputs with colleagues in USAID Missions and Washington working on citizen security issues, and with implementing partners also working in this sector.

title.narrative: EDU: Leadership for Change in Education (Teach for LAC)

description.narrative: (USAID Latin America and Caribbean Regional): This activity is working to improve teacher quality and teacher support resources in low-income and hard-to-staff communities of select countries in the LAC region. The purpose of the activity is to develop collective leadership to improve education quality. With FY 2022 funds, and after an approved extension (requested in Fall 2022), the activity will continue supporting teacher leadership programs through local partners in Colombia, Ecuador, and Paraguay, and the activity will support the establishment of a new teacher leadership program through a local partner in Guatemala. Key interventions and outcomes will include the end line student learning assessments, recruitment and training of new leaders in the teaching profession, family and community engagement, the expansion of education services to additional regions in each country, and alumni network engagement across leadership pathways. Furthermore, given this activity's focus on improving quality education, including for girls, we expect the activity to improve school access and retention rates for girls, which has been proven to reduce child early marriage. This activity supports the WHA-LAC Joint Regional Strategy objective of strengthened health and education system and improved inclusive access by improving the quality of teaching in hard-to-staff and difficult-to-reach schools/communities, which improves access for under-served students, as well as supporting alumni of the teacher leadership programs to become leaders in the education sector over the course of their careers. ..

title.narrative: EDU: Research in Education for Transformative Opportunities (RETO)

description.narrative: (USAID Latin America and Caribbean Regional): Research in Education for Transformative Opportunities (RETO) supports key stakeholders in El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras to more effectively design, implement, and evaluate education programs and policies that contribute to the prevention of youth violence and insecurity. A secure Western Hemisphere is a USG goal made explicit in the U.S. Strategy for Addressing the Root Causes of Migration in Central America, and violence prevention is a development objective in the country-level strategy documents across the Northern Triangle missions. Education programming for youth is part of a multifaceted approach to violence prevention, though a clearer understanding of what works and support with implementing it has been missing in the past. By increasing the quality and relevance of information on education programming for youth violence prevention, RETO helps improve evidence-based decision making among key education stakeholders, thus helping to ensure that investments in improving education are impactful, cost-effective and sustainable, therefore also working to achieve the JRS goal of a prosperous hemisphere through strengthened health and education systems and improved inclusive access. .With FY 2022 funds, RETO will build on the comprehensive education stakeholder maps and evidence gaps maps it has developed by synthesizing and disseminating existing evidence to share with key education stakeholders. They will also work with key stakeholders to collectively turn evidence into action through programs and policies. This will include a collaborative process for strengthening capacity and systems in the region to ensure the use of evidence for decision making well into the future. Finally, they will continue to work with youth by providing internships, building their capacity to synthesize evidence, elevating their voices on violence prevention, and providing youth advocacy training....

title.narrative: Conflict Early Warning, Mitigation and Peace Building

description.narrative: Reduce the threat or impact of violent conflict and promote peaceful resolution of differences, ensure conflict sensitivity so as not to exacerbate sources of violence and/or establish an inclusive framework for peace and reconciliation which addresses all key drivers and mitigators of conflict. This includes activities aimed specifically at atrocities prevention, as well as activities intended to transform relationships to decrease the likelihood of future violent conflict. Develop and support early warning and response mechanisms such as early warning models and response protocols; conflict analysis; monitoring mechanisms and peace structures at different levels; peace building communication systems; confidence-building measures; crisis-response planning and management skills at the local and national levels; and means for rapid and effective response in the event of crisis. Support quick-impact, outcome-based activities required to demonstrate the positive impact of a peace process, operation or other event, such as mobilizing small grants for communities and local/national governments; ensuring delivery of services (e.g., "ministry in a box"); bringing local and national government authorities closer to their constituencies (e.g., town hall meetings, consultations, production and dissemination of information); generating employment for potential spoilers; and managing expectations.

description.narrative: The purpose of the LAC Bureaus Equitable Growth Best Practices project is to assess, distill and disseminate proven development approaches to fostering rapid and equitable trade-led economic growth, in order to guide USAID and local partners policies and programs. By sharing and piloting best practices, the project seeks to catalyze a consensus in favor of programs that improve the enabling environment for business growth. The goal is to provide practitioners and development agents with tools and strategies to generate greater opportunities for poor and disenfranchised populations in the LAC region to contribute to, and benefit from, trade-led economic growth. The objective of this task order is to develop a common approach among implementers for tracking the impact of the USAID funds being programmed under the Portman-Bingaman (hereafter, P-B) earmark for the Dominican Republic, the context of which is described below.

description.narrative: The AIME Cooperative Agreement will increase the participation of marginalized, forest-based communities in "Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degredation" REDD+ and similar projects in order to mitigate global climate change (GCC) emissions. This goal will be achieved by work in three areas: (1) creating tools and approaches that increase the capacity of local communities to engage with the private and public sectors more confidently and productively on resource management in general and carbon credits in particular (Capacity Building); (2) improving the capacity of sub-national governments to play a critical role in community-based REDD+ programs, with a focus on developing legal, regulatory and administrative frameworks to support fair inclusion of indigenous and Afro-descendent communities in REDD+ (Jurisdictional Programs); and (3) bringing community, local and regional government, and private sector representatives together to develop new approaches to negotiate REDD+ contracts and/or support REDD+ compatible activities (e.g., agroforestry community micro-enterprises). Beneficiary countries include Colombia, Peru, Brazil, Mexico, and the Central America Regional Mission.

description.narrative: Through an interagency agreement, LAC/RP is working with USDA to assist stakeholders in the LAC region to prepare food-exporting value chains to comply with anticipated requirements of the U.S. Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA).~ USDA, along with implementing partners like the Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture (IICA), will conduct FSMA readiness assessments and provide practical food safety, food defense, and monitoring technical assistance within a train-the-trainer context.

title.narrative: Central American Regional Security Initiative Technical Support Services (CARSI TSS)

description.narrative: To help USAID and other agencies working to change this reality under the Central American Regional Security Initiative (CARSI), the Technical Support Services (TSS) project provided support and technical expertise to identify best practices and fosterexchange and learning on crime and violence prevention in the region. The results of this work were critical to helping CARSI partners and implementers better understand and collaboratively address the serious challenges facing Central America.

title.narrative: Clean Energy IDIQ N-CPC (ECODIT): Clean Energy Finance Facility for the Caribbean and Central America (CEFF-CCA)

description.narrative: CEFF-CCA focuses on helping promising but undercapitalized projects answer core, early-stage technical, business, financial and other feasibility questions that too often derail projects and keep them from securing financing. The CEFF-CCA will target both utility scale and distributed (e.g., on commercial and industrial buildings, hotel and resort properties) renewable and clean energy projects. Assistance will be provided through grants that allow project developers to carry out legal, technical, engineering and other studies they need to be able to bring their project to bankable status.

Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

title.narrative: CARSI-ESF-Regional DC Crime Prevention in Central America

description.narrative: LAC/RP will continue activities through Municipal Partnerships for Violence Prevention in the development of a regional network of municipalities working on crime prevention in Central America and the Dominican Republic. This program will also carry out exchanges between municipal actors from Central America, the U.S., and potentially others from across and beyond the LAC region to share and implement successful municipally-based crime prevention activities. LAC/RP funds will be used to increase municipal awareness of trafficking in persons and help municipal leaders integrate trafficking in persons prevention into their crime and violence prevention activities.*****(State Western Hemisphere Regional): Municipal Partnerships for Violence Prevention in Central America. Funds will be used to continue activities with ICMA in the development of a regional network of municipalities in Central America working on crime prevention. This program will also carry on exchanges between municipal actors from Central America, the U.S., and potentially others from across and beyond the LAC region to share and implement successful municipally-based crime prevention activities. Funds will allow the program to increase sustainability of the regional network beyond the life of the program and to build trilateral partnerships between Central American and other Latin American countries on municipal-level crime and violence prevention.

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Support the development of effective, legitimate, and democratically accountable security systems (within the statutory restrictions on providing support to law enforcement forces). Illustrative activities include the following: public sector reform and public management; strategic planning, policy, and budget formulation; building ministry capacity; civilian and civic capacity building; formal oversight (legislative, fiscal, human rights); and informal oversight (civil society watchdog groups).

Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Objective, when applicable and appropriate.
